FedCor: Correlation-Based Active Client Selection Strategy for Heterogeneous Federated Learning

Minxue Tang1, Xuefei Ning2, Yitu Wang1, Jingwei Sun1, Yu Wang2, Hai Li1, Yiran Chen1
1Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University
2Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University
1{minxue.tang,yitu.wang,jingwei.sun,hai.li,yiran.chen}@duke.edu
2foxdoraame@gmail.com â€ƒ2yu-wang@tsinghua.edu.cn Corresponding Author
Abstract

Client-wise data heterogeneity is one of the major issues that hinder effective training in federated learning (FL). Since the data distribution on each client may vary dramatically, the client selection strategy can significantly influence the convergence rate of the FL process. Active client selection strategies are popularly proposed in recent studies. However, they neglect the loss correlations between the clients and achieve only marginal improvement compared to the uniform selection strategy. In this work, we propose FedCorâ€”an FL framework built on a correlation-based client selection strategy, to boost the convergence rate of FL. Specifically, we first model the loss correlations between the clients with a Gaussian Process (GP). Based on the GP model, we derive a client selection strategy with a significant reduction of expected global loss in each round. Besides, we develop an efficient GP training method with a low communication overhead in the FL scenario by utilizing the covariance stationarity. Our experimental results show that compared to the state-of-the-art method, FedCorr can improve the convergence rates by 34%âˆ¼99%similar-topercent34percent9934\%\sim 99\% and 26%âˆ¼51%similar-topercent26percent5126\%\sim 51\% on FMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively.

1 Introduction

As a newly emerging distributed learning paradigm, federated learning (FL)Â [12, 13, 23, 9, 17] has recently attracted attention because of the offered data privacy. FL aims at dealing with scenarios where training data is distributed across a number of clients. Considering limited communication bandwidth and the privacy requirement, in each communication round, FL usually selects only a fraction of clients, and the selected clients will perform multiple iterations of local updating without exposing their own datasetsÂ [23]. This special scenario also introduces other challenges that distinguish FL from the conventional distributed learningÂ [2, 35].

One major challenge in FL is the high degree of client-wise data heterogeneityÂ [17], which is the inherent characteristic of a large number of clients. There have been many studiesÂ [27, 18, 20, 10, 32, 25, 16, 15] trying to tackle non-IID (independent and identically distributed) and unbalanced data of the clients in FL. Most of these studiesÂ [18, 20, 10, 32] focus on amending the local model updates or the central aggregation based on FedAvgÂ [23].

Recently, active client selection arises as a complement of the aforementioned studies, aiming at accelerating the convergence of FL with non-IID data. Some recent studies propose to assign higher probability of being selected to the clients with larger training loss valueÂ [6, 4]. However, they neglect the correlations between the clients and consider their losses independently, which leads to only marginal performance improvement. In this paper, we propose a correlation-based active client selection strategy that can effectively alleviate the accuracy degradation caused by data heterogeneity and significantly boost the convergence of FL. Our key idea is mainly based on the following intuitions:

  1. 1.

    Clients do not contribute equivalently. For example, training with a large and balanced dataset on a â€œgoodâ€ client can reduce the losses of most clients, while training with a small and extremely biased dataset on a â€œbadâ€ client may increase the losses of other clients.

  2. 2.

    Clients do not contribute independently. The influence of selecting one client depends on the other selected clients because their local updates will be aggregated.

A toy experiment shown in Fig.Â 1 also illustrates the necessity of considering the correlations for client selection. In this experiment, each client has only one data sample, and thus each data point in the figure represents a client. The task is to select two clients (different markers represent the client selections of different strategies) for training a binary classifier (shown as the lines). The selection strategy that independently selects two clients with the highest local losses (â€œInd Resultâ€) fails to reduce the global loss. In contrast, our method considers the correlations between the clients (â€œCor Resultâ€) and derives a client selection that can achieve an almost lowest global loss (â€œOpt Resultâ€).

Based on the above intuitions, this work proposes FedCor, an FL framework built on a correlation-based client selection strategy, to boost the convergence of FL. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We model the client loss changes with a Gaussian Process (GP) and propose an interpretable client selection strategy with a significant reduction of the expected global loss in each communication round.

  2. 2.

    We propose a GP training method that utilizes the covariance stationarity to reduce the communication cost. Experiments show that the GP trained with our method can capture the client correlations well.

  3. 3.

    Experimental results demonstrate that FedCor stabilizes the training convergence and significantly improves the convergence rates by 34%âˆ¼99%similar-topercent34percent9934\%\sim 99\% and 26%âˆ¼51%similar-topercent26percent5126\%\sim 51\% on FMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively.

2 Related Work

An important characteristic of FLÂ [12, 13, 23] is the heterogeneity of clients, which raises new challenges of the trainingÂ [9, 17, 31]. There are two kinds of heterogeneity in FL: systemic heterogeneity (computation ability, communication bandwidth, etc.) and statistical heterogeneity (non-IID, imbalanced data distribution)Â [18, 17]. This work mainly focuses on the latter one. A number of methods have been proposed to improve the basic FL algorithm, FedAvgÂ [23], in heterogeneous settings. Some of them manipulate the local training loss like adding regularization terms to stabilized the trainingÂ [18, 26, 20, 10, 8], while some other works amend the aggregation method to reduce the varianceÂ [32, 24].

Complementary to such methods, another way to improve the convergence of FL in non-IID settings is active client selection, which tries to strategically select clients for training in each round in stead of uniformly selecting. Goetz et al.Â [6] first propose to assign a high selection probability to the clients with large local loss. Cho et al.Â [4] select Cğ¶C clients with the largest loss among a randomly sampled subset ğ”¸âŠ†ğ•Œğ”¸ğ•Œ{\mathbb{A}}\subseteq{\mathbb{U}} with size d>Cğ‘‘ğ¶d>C to reduce the selection bias. However, neither of them consider the correlations between clients while making the client selection.

4 Methodology

In this section, we elaborate our proposed method, i.e., FedCor, that can effectively boost the convergence of FL. We first formulate our goal of accelerating the convergence of FL as optimization problems that maximize the posterior expectation of loss decrease in Sec.Â 4.1. Then, Sec.Â 4.2 demonstrates empirical evidence that the prior distribution of loss changes in each communication round can be modeled as Gaussian Processes (GP). Based on this observation, we utilize GP to solve the optimization problems and obtain an effective client selection strategy for heterogeneous FL in Sec.Â 4.3. We further analyze the selection criterion of our client selection strategy and give out its intuitive interpretation in Sec.Â 4.4. Finally, in Sec.Â 4.5, we describe how we train the GP parameters in communication-constrained FL.

4.1 Problem Formulation

To achieve a fast convergence, we hope to find the client selection strategy which can lead to the maximal global loss decrease after each communication round. Accordingly, we define our target as solving a series of optimization problems, one for each communication round tğ‘¡t:

minğ•‚tsubscriptsubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡\displaystyle\min_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}} Î”â€‹Ltâ€‹(ğ•‚t)=Lâ€‹(ğ’˜t+1â€‹(ğ•‚t))âˆ’Lâ€‹(ğ’˜t)Î”superscriptğ¿ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ¿superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡1subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ¿superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle\Delta L^{t}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})=L({\bm{w}}^{t+1}({\mathbb{K}}_{t}))-L({\bm{w}}^{t}) (6)
subject to ğ’˜t+1â€‹(ğ•‚t)=ğ’˜tâˆ’Î·tCâ€‹âˆ‘kâˆˆğ•‚tâˆ‡~â€‹lkâ€‹(ğ’˜t).superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡1subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ¶subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘™ğ‘˜superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle{\bm{w}}^{t+1}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})={\bm{w}}^{t}-\frac{\eta_{t}}{C}\sum_{k\in{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}\tilde{\nabla}l_{k}({\bm{w}}^{t}).

It is impractical in FL to search for the best client selection with multiple trials of different client selections since it introduces large communication and computation overhead. Therefore, we need an efficient way to predict the global loss decreases for different client selections and make a decision with very limited trials. To achieve this goal, we first reformulate the optimization problem in Eq.Â 6 with the following lemma. The proof of this lemma is in Sec.Â A.2.

Lemma 1.

The optimization problem in Eq.Â 6 is approximately equivalent to the following probabilistic form.

minğ•‚tğ”¼Î”â€‹ğ¥t|Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t)â€‹[âˆ‘ipiâ€‹Î”â€‹lit]=âˆ‘ipiâ€‹Î¼~itâ€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t)),subscriptsubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼conditionalÎ”superscriptğ¥ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡delimited-[]subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscript~ğœ‡ğ‘¡ğ‘–Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡\min_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}\quad\mathbb{E}_{\Delta{\mathbf{l}}^{t}|\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})}\Big{[}\sum_{i}p_{i}\Delta l^{t}_{i}\Big{]}=\sum_{i}p_{i}\tilde{\mu}^{t}_{i}(\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})), (7)

where Î”â€‹ğ¥t=[Î”â€‹l1t,â‹¯,Î”â€‹lNt]Î”superscriptğ¥ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptlğ‘¡1â‹¯Î”subscriptsuperscriptlğ‘¡ğ‘\Delta{\mathbf{l}}^{t}=[\Delta{\textnormal{l}}^{t}_{1},\cdots,\Delta{\textnormal{l}}^{t}_{N}] is the loss changes of all clients in round tğ‘¡t, which is a random variable w.r.t random client selection in round tğ‘¡t. ğ›~tâ€‹(Î”â€‹ğ¥ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t))superscript~ğ›ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡\tilde{\bm{\mu}}^{t}(\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})) is the posterior mean of Î”â€‹ğ¥tÎ”superscriptğ¥ğ‘¡\Delta{\mathbf{l}}^{t} conditioned on Î”â€‹ğ¥ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t)=[Î”â€‹litâ€‹(ğ•‚t)]iâˆˆğ•‚tÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptdelimited-[]Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})=[\Delta l^{t}_{i}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})]_{i\in{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}.

The reformulated objective in Eq.Â 7 tells that if we can predict the loss changes of those clients selected for training (Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t)Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})), we can predict the global loss change with its posterior mean and make decision according to it. Now what we need is a probabilistic model of the loss changes Î”â€‹ğ¥tÎ”superscriptğ¥ğ‘¡\Delta{\mathbf{l}}^{t} to make the prediction and calculate the posterior.

4.2 Modeling Loss Changes with GP

It is a common practice to assume a GP prior over an unknown objective function in Bayesian OptimizationÂ [3, 30]. Our preliminary investigation (partly) shown in Fig.Â 2 also indicates that the prior distribution of the loss changes in one communication round follow a GP. Specifically, we randomly sample a number of client selections and perform one round of training to get samples of the loss changes. Then, we conduct PCA on these loss change samples and plot histograms of the first several principle components. The red line in the Fig.Â 2 is the Gaussian PDF with the sample mean and sample variance. And we can see that this Gaussian distribution can approximate the distribution of the samples well. A mathematical explanation of this observation is also given out in Sec.Â A.1.

Accordingly, we propose to model the loss changes in one communication round tğ‘¡t with a GP prior as follows:

Î”â€‹ğ¥t=[Î”â€‹l1t,â‹¯,Î”â€‹lNt]âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’t;ğt,ğšºt).Î”superscriptğ¥ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptlğ‘¡1â‹¯Î”subscriptsuperscriptlğ‘¡ğ‘similar-toğ’©Î”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡superscriptğğ‘¡superscriptğšºğ‘¡\Delta{\mathbf{l}}^{t}=[\Delta{\textnormal{l}}^{t}_{1},\cdots,\Delta{\textnormal{l}}^{t}_{N}]\sim\mathcal{N}(\Delta\bm{l}^{t};\bm{\mu}^{t},\bm{\Sigma}^{t}). (8)

Remark. In order to efficiently learn the covariance in FL, rather than directly working with the covariance matrix, we embed all clients into a continuous vector space and use a kernel function to calculate the covariance (see Sec.Â 4.5). Thus, we still use the term GP instead of Multivariate Gaussian Distribution, though the dimension of Î”â€‹ğ¥tÎ”superscriptğ¥ğ‘¡\Delta{\mathbf{l}}^{t} is finite.

A good property of GP is that we can get a closed form of the posterior expectation in Eq.Â 7, which makes our client selection strategy interpretable. In the next sections, we will propose our client selection strategy based on the GP model, and then give an interpretation of it. We leave the training method for the parameters (ğt,ğšºtsuperscriptğğ‘¡superscriptğšºğ‘¡\bm{\mu}^{t},\bm{\Sigma}^{t}) in GP to Sec.Â 4.5.

4.3 Client Selection Strategy

While we have get the probabilistic model to calculate the posterior expectation, it is still not determined how to predict the loss changes of the clients selected for training, namely Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t)Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t}). Inspired by UCB methods[5, 1, 28], we develop an iterative method that predict the loss change and select one client in each iteration, as shown in AlgorithmÂ 1. There are three steps in one iteration:

(i) Prediction. In each iteration, we first make an prediction Î”â€‹l^ktÎ”subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\Delta\hat{l}^{t}_{k} for each client kğ‘˜k if it is selected. Generally, the selected client would have a large loss decrease since it directly participate in the model update. Thus, we propose to use the lower confidence bound as the prediction:

Î”â€‹l^ktÎ”superscriptsubscript^ğ‘™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle\Delta\hat{l}_{k}^{t} =Î¼ktâˆ’Î±ktâ€‹Ïƒkt;Î±kt=aâ€‹Î²Ï„kt,formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ›½superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mu_{k}^{t}-\alpha_{k}^{t}\sigma_{k}^{t};\quad\alpha_{k}^{t}=a\beta^{\tau_{k}^{t}}, (9)

where Ïƒkt=Î£k,ktsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘˜\sigma_{k}^{t}=\sqrt{\Sigma^{t}_{k,k}}, and ağ‘a is a scale constant. Î²âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›½01\beta\in(0,1) is an annealing coefficient, and its index Ï„ktsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¡\tau_{k}^{t} denotes how many times client kğ‘˜k has been selected. We will discuss this annealing coefficient more in Sec.Â 4.5.

(ii) Selection. The client kâˆ—superscriptğ‘˜k^{*} is selected to minimize the posterior expectation of the overall loss conditioned on its loss change prediction made in the last step:

kâˆ—=argâ¡minkâˆ‘ipiâ€‹Î¼~itâ€‹(Î”â€‹l^kt)superscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscript~ğœ‡ğ‘¡ğ‘–Î”superscriptsubscript^ğ‘™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡k^{*}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{k}\sum_{i}p_{i}\tilde{\mu}^{t}_{i}(\Delta\hat{l}_{k}^{t}) (10)

(iii) Posterior. After selecting the client kâˆ—superscriptğ‘˜k^{*}, we update the GP for the next iteration with the posterior conditioned on the loss change prediction of kâˆ—superscriptğ‘˜k^{*}:

ğtâ†ğ~tâ€‹(Î”â€‹l^kâˆ—t),ğšºtâ†ğšº~tâ€‹(Î”â€‹l^kâˆ—t).formulae-sequenceâ†superscriptğğ‘¡superscript~ğğ‘¡Î”superscriptsubscript^ğ‘™superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â†superscriptğšºğ‘¡superscript~ğšºğ‘¡Î”superscriptsubscript^ğ‘™superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{\mu}^{t}\leftarrow\tilde{\bm{\mu}}^{t}(\Delta\hat{l}_{k^{*}}^{t}),\quad\bm{\Sigma}^{t}\leftarrow\tilde{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t}(\Delta\hat{l}_{k^{*}}^{t}). (11)

By updating the GP with its posterior, we iteratively add conditions into the probabilistic model to approach the fully conditioned distribution pâ€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’t|Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚ttâ€‹(ğ•‚t))ğ‘conditionalÎ”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡p(\Delta\bm{l}^{t}|\Delta\bm{l}^{t}_{{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})), and make the next prediction of the loss change more accurate.

There are some similarities between our method and traditional Bayesian Optimization: Using GP as a prior of the objective function, and using UCB as well as posterior distribution for iterative selectionÂ [5, 3, 28]. However, there is a key difference: In each communication round, we determine the client selection with only predictions instead of measurements of the global loss changes, while traditional Bayesian Optimization requires a sequence of measurements as new information to make decisions. The measurements of global loss changes will introduce large communication overhead and are unfeasible in FL.

4.4 Insights into Our Selection Strategy

In this section, we give an intuitive interpretation of our selection strategy and show the benefits of it within a simple case. A more detailed analysis of the selection criterion and convergence of FedCor can be found in AppendixÂ B.

For simplicity, we omit all superscript tğ‘¡t in this section. LemmaÂ 2 gives the selection criterion of FedCor in a simple case where we only select two clients, and the proof can be found in Sec.Â A.3.

Lemma 2.

The selection criterion of FedCor when selecting two clients k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} and k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} can be written as

where riâ€‹j=Î£i,j/Ïƒiâ€‹Ïƒjsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptÎ£ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘—r_{ij}=\Sigma_{i,j}/\sigma_{i}\sigma_{j} is the Pearson correlation coefficient.

(i) Single-Iteration. Eq.Â 12 has a clear interpretation to select the client that has large correlations with other clients (riâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜r_{ik}), so that other clients can benefit more from training on the selected client. Our selection criterion takes the correlations between the clients into consideration, and can conduct better selection compared with those algorithms that only consider the loss of each client independentlyÂ [6, 4].

(ii) Multi-Iteration. In Eq.Â 13, term (A) and (B) are the single-iteration selection criterion in Eq.Â 12 of client kâ€²superscriptğ‘˜â€²k^{\prime} and k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, respectively. Since we have maximized (B) when selecting client k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, term (B) is usually positive. Therefore, the selection of kâ€²superscriptğ‘˜â€²k^{\prime} does not only consider its correlations with other clients (riâ€‹kâ€²subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ‘˜â€²r_{ik^{\prime}}), but also prefers the clients that have small correlations rk1â€‹kâ€²subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘˜â€²r_{k_{1}k^{\prime}} with the previous selected client k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}. This criterion penalizes selection redundancy and leads to a client selection with diverse data, which reduces the variance and makes the training process more stable. Since clients with similar data generate similar local updates, selecting redundant clients only brings marginal gains to the global performance or would even drive the optimization into bad local optimum. This selection preference is also demonstrated in Fig.Â 1, where FedCor chooses one positive and one negative point as the optimal selection does.

4.5 Training GP in FL

As a classical machine learning model, GP has been widely discussed and well studiedÂ [33]. There have been many methods to train the parameters in GP, namely, the covariance ğšºtsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡\bm{\Sigma}^{t} in Eq.Â 8 111We do not train ğğ\bm{\mu} and set it to ğŸ0\bm{0}, since it does not affect the selection strategy as we can see in LemmaÂ 2 and AppendixÂ B.. Nevertheless, to make the GP training feasible in the communication-constrained FL procedure, we should revise the GP training method to reduce the number of samples and better utilize historical information.

In GP, a kernel function Kâ€‹(ğ’™i,ğ’™j)ğ¾subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘—K(\bm{x}_{i},\bm{x}_{j}) is used to calculate the covarianceÂ [33] as Î£i,jt=Kâ€‹(ğ’™it,ğ’™jt)subscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘—ğ‘¡\Sigma^{t}_{i,j}=K(\bm{x}_{i}^{t},\bm{x}_{j}^{t}), where ğ’™it,ğ’™jtsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘—ğ‘¡\bm{x}_{i}^{t},\bm{x}_{j}^{t} are the features of the data points iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j, respectively. Following this, we assign a trainable embedding in a latent space to each client. The embedding of the kğ‘˜k-th client is noted as ğ’™ktâˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{x}_{k}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (d<Nğ‘‘ğ‘d<N), and we choose the kernel function as

Kâ€‹(ğ’™it,ğ’™jt)=ğ’™itTâ€‹ğ’™jt,ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘—ğ‘¡superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘—ğ‘¡K(\bm{x}_{i}^{t},\bm{x}_{j}^{t})={\bm{x}_{i}^{t}}^{T}\bm{x}_{j}^{t}, (14)

which is a homogeneous linear kernelÂ [33]. This low-rank formulation reduces the number of parameters we need to learn, thus making the GP training more data-efficient.

A commonly used GP training method is maximum likelihood evaluation, where we uniformly sample Sğ‘†S client selection {ğ•Št,i:i=1,â‹¯,S}conditional-setsubscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘†\{{\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}:i=1,\cdots,S\}, and maximize the likelihood of the corresponding loss changes {Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•Št,i):i=1,â‹¯,S}conditional-setÎ”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘†\{\Delta\bm{l}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}):i=1,\cdots,S\} to learn the embedding matrix ğ‘¿t=[ğ’™1t,â‹¯,ğ’™Nt]superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™1ğ‘¡â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ğ‘¡{\bm{X}}^{t}=[{\bm{x}}_{1}^{t},\cdots,{\bm{x}}_{N}^{t}]:

ğ‘¿t=argâ¡maxğ‘¿âˆ‘i=1Slogâ¡pâ€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•Št,i)|ğ‘¿).superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘†ğ‘conditionalÎ”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘¿{\bm{X}}^{t}=\mathop{\arg\max}_{{\bm{X}}}\sum_{i=1}^{S}\log p(\Delta\bm{l}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i})|{\bm{X}}). (15)

However, to collect each sample Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•Št,i)Î”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–\Delta\bm{l}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}), we have to broadcast ğ’˜t+1â€‹(ğ•Št,i)superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡1subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bm{w}}^{t+1}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}) to all the clients. And since a large Sğ‘†S is usually required for an unbiased estimation in each communication round tğ‘¡t, the vanilla training procedure in Eq.Â 15 introduces a high communication overhead.

Actually, the correlations between loss changes of different clients mainly arise from similarities between their datasets, which are invariant during the FL process. Thus, we hypothesise that the covariance also changes slowly in the concerned time range. To verify this, we use a large number of samples to evaluate the covariance ğšºtsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡\bm{\Sigma}^{t} in each communication round, and calculate the cosine similarity between ğšºtsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡\bm{\Sigma}^{t} and ğšºt+Î”â€‹tsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡Î”ğ‘¡\bm{\Sigma}^{t+\Delta t}. We set Î”â€‹t=10Î”ğ‘¡10\Delta t=10 for FMNIST and Î”â€‹t=50Î”ğ‘¡50\Delta t=50 for CIFAR-10. As shown in Fig.Â 3, we can see that the similarity keeps very high (>0.97absent0.97>0.97 for FMNIST and >0.95absent0.95>0.95 for CIFAR-10) during the whole FL training process.

Accordingly, we do not need to update ğ‘¿tsuperscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡{\bm{X}}^{t} in every round but inherit the embedding matrix ğ‘¿tâˆ’1superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡1{\bm{X}}^{t-1} from the last round and train it only every Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t rounds. Furthermore, we can reuse historical samples for GP training to reduce the number of samples Sğ‘†S that we need to collect in each GP training round. We summarize our update rule of ğ‘¿tsuperscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡{\bm{X}}^{t} as follows:

ğ‘¿t={ğ‘¿tâˆ’1,t%â€‹Î”â€‹tâ‰ 0;argâ¡maxğ‘¿Î¦tâ€‹(ğ‘¿),t%â€‹Î”â€‹t=0,superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡casessuperscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡1percentğ‘¡Î”ğ‘¡0otherwisesubscriptğ‘¿subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¿percentğ‘¡Î”ğ‘¡0otherwise\displaystyle{\bm{X}}^{t}=\begin{cases}{\bm{X}}^{t-1},\quad t\%\Delta t\neq 0;\\ \mathop{\arg\max}_{\bm{X}}\Phi_{t}({\bm{X}}),\quad t\%\Delta t=0,\end{cases} (16)

where

Î¦tâ€‹(ğ‘¿)=âˆ‘m=0Mâˆ‘i=1SÎ³mâ€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’tâˆ’mâ€‹Î”â€‹tâ€‹(ğ•Štâˆ’mâ€‹Î”â€‹t,i)|ğ‘¿).subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘š0ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘†superscriptğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘conditionalÎ”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡ğ‘šÎ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘šÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘¿\displaystyle\Phi_{t}({\bm{X}})=\sum_{m=0}^{M}\sum_{i=1}^{S}\gamma^{m}\log p(\Delta\bm{l}^{t-m\Delta t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t-m\Delta t,i})|{\bm{X}}). (17)

Mğ‘€M is the number of reused historical samples, and Î³<1ğ›¾1\gamma<1 is the discount factor to weight the historical samples. Our method is able to reduce the communication overhead with a large Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t and S=1ğ‘†1S=1, while guaranteeing the performance.

As we only update the covariance ğšºğšº\bm{\Sigma} every Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t rounds, the annealing factor Î²Ï„ksuperscriptğ›½subscriptğœğ‘˜\beta^{\tau_{k}} can prevent us from making the same selection during the Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t rounds. Repeatedly training with the same group of clients would cause the global model to overfit on their data, which may hinder the convergence of FL. In practice, we reset Ï„ksubscriptğœğ‘˜\tau_{k} to 00 after each GP training round to achieve the fastest convergence while avoiding overfitting on some clients.

We summarize our overall framework FedCor in AlgorithmÂ 2. It is noteworthy that our method is orthogonal to existing FL optimizers that amend the training loss or the aggregation scheme, e.g., FedAvgÂ [23] and FedProxÂ [18]. So our method can be combined with any of them.

5 Experiments

5.1 Experiment Settings

We conduct experiments on two datasets, FMNISTÂ [34] and CIFAR-10Â [14]. For FMNIST, we adopt an MLP model with two hidden layers, and this model achieves an accuracy of 85.92%percent85.9285.92\% with centralized training. For CIFAR-10, we adopt a CNN model with three convolutional layers followed by one fully connected layer, and this model can achieve an accuracy of 73.84%percent73.8473.84\% with centralized training. More details on the model construction and training hyperparameters can be found in Sec.Â C.1. For each dataset, we experiment with three different heterogeneous data partitions on N=100ğ‘100N=100 clients as follows.

(i) 2 shards per client (2SPC): This setting is the same as the non-IID setting in [23]. We sort the data by their labels and divide them into 200200200 shards so that all the data in one shard share the same label. We randomly allocate these shards to clients, and each client has two shards. Since all the shards have the same size, the data partition is balanced. That is to say, all the clients have the same dataset size. We select C=5ğ¶5C=5 clients in each round within this setting.

(ii) 1 shard per client (1SPC): This setting is similar to the 2SPC setting, and the only difference is that each client only has one shard, i.e., each client only has the data of one label. This is the data partition with the highest heterogeneity, and it is also balanced. We select C=10ğ¶10C=10 clients in each round within this setting.

(iii) Dirichlet Distribution with Î±=0.2ğ›¼0.2\alpha=0.2 (Dir): We inherit and slightly change the setting from [7] to create an unbalanced data partition. We sample the ratio of the data with each label on one client from a Dirichlet Distribution parameterized by the concentration parameter Î±=0.2ğ›¼0.2\alpha=0.2. More details can be found in the AppendixÂ C.2. We select C=5ğ¶5C=5 clients in each round within this setting.

We divide the training process of FedCor into two phases: (i) Warm-up phase: We uniformly sample client selection ğ•‚tsubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡{\mathbb{K}}_{t} and collect the loss values of all the clients in ğ•Œğ•Œ{\mathbb{U}} to train the GP in each round, i.e., Î”â€‹t=1Î”ğ‘¡1\Delta t=1 and S=1ğ‘†1S=1. We set the length of the warm-up phase to 151515 for FMNIST and 202020 for CIFAR-10. (ii) Normal phase: After the warm-up phase, we follow AlgorithmÂ 2 to select clients and update the GP.

In all the experiments, we use FedAvgÂ [23] as the FL optimizer. We present the average results using five random seeds in all experiments. We will first show that our method can achieve faster and more stable convergence, compared with three baselines: random selection (Rand), Active FL (AFL)Â [6] and Power-of-choice Selection Strategy (Pow-d)Â [4]. Then, we will give ablation studies on the GP training interval Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t as well as the annealing coefficient Î²ğ›½\beta. Finally, we visualize the client embeddings ğ‘¿ğ‘¿{\bm{X}} with t-SNEÂ [21] and show that FedCor can effectively capture the correlations.

5.2 Convergence under Heterogeneous Settings

We compare the convergence rate of our method FedCor with the other baselines on both FMNIST and CIFAR-10, and demonstrate the results in FigureÂ 4. We set the GP update interval Î”â€‹t=10Î”ğ‘¡10\Delta t=10 and the annealing coefficient Î²=0.95ğ›½0.95\beta=0.95 for FMNIST experiments, and Î”â€‹t=50Î”ğ‘¡50\Delta t=50 and Î²=0.9ğ›½0.9\beta=0.9 for CIFAR-10 experiments.

As shown in FigureÂ 4, FedCor achieves the highest test accuracy and the fastest convergence in all experiments. While other active client selection strategies show only slight or even no superiority compared with the fully random strategy, our method clearly outperforms all baselines, especially under the extremely heterogeneous setting when data on each client contains only one label (1SPC). Furthermore, the learning curves of FedCor are more smooth and less noisy than those of other methods, meaning that FedCor reduces the variance and makes the federated optimization more stable.

TableÂ 1 shows the numbers of communication rounds for each selection strategy to achieve a specified test accuracy. We can see that FedCor achieves the specified accuracy 34%âˆ¼99%similar-topercent34percent9934\%\sim 99\% and 26%âˆ¼51%similar-topercent26percent5126\%\sim 51\% faster than Pow-d on FMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively.

5.3 Results with Larger GP Training Interval

Collecting training data in the GP update rounds brings communication overhead, since we need to broadcast the model to all the clients. Thus, it is important to investigate the minimal GP update frequency. We vary the GP training interval and show the accuracy curves in FigureÂ 5. We set Î”â€‹t=10,20,500Î”ğ‘¡1020500\Delta t=10,20,500 with Î²=0.95,0.95,0.99ğ›½0.950.950.99\beta=0.95,0.95,0.99 for the experiments on FMNIST, and Î”â€‹t=50,100,2000Î”ğ‘¡501002000\Delta t=50,100,2000 with Î²=0.97,0.97,0.999ğ›½0.970.970.999\beta=0.97,0.97,0.999 for the experiments on CIFAR-10, respectively. As shown in the figures, the performance degrades very slightly with larger training intervals. It is noteworthy that even if we do not update the GP model after the warm-up phase (noted as Î”â€‹t=500Î”ğ‘¡500\Delta t=500 for FMNIST, and Î”â€‹t=2000Î”ğ‘¡2000\Delta t=2000 for CIFAR-10), FedCor still achieves faster convergence than the random selection strategy. These results indicate that the correlations learned by the GP model are stable, which supports our assumption in SectionÂ 4.5. In a word, one can largely reduce the communication overhead by training the GP model with a very low frequency while guaranteeing the convergence rate and accuracy under the communication-bounded FL setting.

5.4 Influence of Annealing Coefficient

We also conduct experiments with different annealing coefficient Î²ğ›½\beta that controls how â€œconcentratedâ€ the client selection is. We perform FedCor with Î”â€‹t=10Î”ğ‘¡10\Delta t=10 and Î²=0.5,0.75,0.9ğ›½0.50.750.9\beta=0.5,0.75,0.9 for FMNIST, and Î”â€‹t=50,Î²=0.9,0.95,0.99formulae-sequenceÎ”ğ‘¡50ğ›½0.90.950.99\Delta t=50,\beta=0.9,0.95,0.99 for CIFAR-10. The learning curves as well as the client selection frequencies under 2SPC setting are shown in Fig.Â 6, and we leave the full results under the 1SPC and Dir settings to Sec.Â D.1. We observe that when using a smaller Î²ğ›½\beta, the overall client selections appear to be more â€œuniformâ€, while the learning curves are almost invariant. Notice that this does not mean that FedCor with small Î²ğ›½\beta is equivalent to uniform sampling, instead, FedCor still achieves consistent improvements compared to uniform sampling. And Sec.Â 4.4 havs discussed the reason: FedCor not only considers the benefit that each client brings to the federation, but also considers the correlations among the clients to select the best group of clients. The experimental results here show that it is more important to select a good â€œgroupâ€ of clients than just good individuals.

5.5 Visualization of Client Embedding

To obtain an insight into the correlations learned by the GP model, we show the t-SNEÂ [21] plot of the client embeddings learned in the warm-up phase under the 1SPC setting. In Fig.Â 7, each embedding is labeled with the only data label on the corresponding client. We normalize the length of embedding vectors to 111 so that the distance between two embeddings can reveal the correlation. We can see that the embeddings of clients with the same label are clustered together, which demonstrates that FedCor has captured the correlations between clients correctly in the warm-up phase.

6 Conclusion and Future Work

This work proposes FedCor, an FL framework with a novel client selection strategy for heterogeneous settings. FedCor is based on the intuition that it is crucial to utilize the correlations between clients to achieve a faster and more stable convergence in heterogeneous FL. Specifically, we model the client correlations with a GP, and design an effective and interpretable client selection strategy based on it. We also develop a efficient method to train the GP with a low communication overhead. Experimental results on FMNIST and CIFAR-10 show that FedCor effectively accelerates and stabilizes the training process under highly heterogeneous settings. In addition, we verify that FedCor captures the client correlation correctly using only the loss information. How to extend FedCor to the other tasks and further utilize the captured correlations is an interesting direction for future work. Besides, our method focuses on the cross-silo federated learning scenarioÂ [9], and how to extend it to the cross-device scenario is a meaningful topic.

Appendix A Theoretical Analysis

A.1 Analytical Insight into Gaussian Processes

In this section, we give a mathematical explanation about why the loss changes obey Gaussian Distributions. Our analysis based on the following assumption where we assume that the global weight update in one communication round follow a Gaussian Distribution under uniformly client selection.

Assumption 1.

In any communication round tğ‘¡t, if the client selection ğ•‚tsubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡{\mathbb{K}}_{t} is a random variable sampled from a uniform distribution, the global model update Î”â€‹ğ°tâ€‹(ğ•‚t)=ğ°t+1â€‹(ğ•‚t)âˆ’ğ°tÎ”superscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğ‘¡\Delta{\mathbf{w}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})={\mathbf{w}}^{t+1}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})-{\bm{w}}^{t} follows Gaussian Distribution, i.e.,

ğ•‚tâˆ¼Uniformâ€‹({ğ•‚âŠ†ğ•Œ:|ğ•‚|=C})similar-tosubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡Uniformconditional-setğ•‚ğ•Œğ•‚ğ¶\displaystyle{\mathbb{K}}_{t}\sim{\rm Uniform}\big{(}\{{\mathbb{K}}\subseteq{\mathbb{U}}:|{\mathbb{K}}|=C\}\big{)} (18)
â‡’â‡’\displaystyle\Rightarrow Î”â€‹ğ°tâ€‹(ğ•‚t)âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’˜t;âˆ’Î·tâ€‹ğ’ˆ~t,Î·t2â€‹ğ‘©â€‹ğ‘©TC),similar-toÎ”superscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ’©Î”superscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscript~ğ’ˆğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2ğ‘©superscriptğ‘©ğ‘‡ğ¶\displaystyle\Delta{\mathbf{w}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}}_{t})\sim\mathcal{N}(\Delta{\bm{w}}^{t};-\eta_{t}\tilde{{\bm{g}}}^{t},\frac{\eta_{t}^{2}{\bm{B}}{\bm{B}}^{T}}{C}),

AssumptionÂ 1 is inspired by [22] who assumes the stochastic gradients in SGD are Gaussian, and therefore the parameter update after one iteration follows a Gaussian Distribution. Note that in the FL procedure, the form in Eq.Â 5 is very similar to that in the SGD update. The only difference is that the average gradients within one mini-batch is replaced by the average cumulative gradients of the selected clients. Therefore, it is reasonable to make this assumption similar to [22].

To make a distinction, we use Î”â€‹ğ°Î”ğ°\Delta{\mathbf{w}} without parentheses to denote a random variable w.r.t. the uniformly sampled client selection, and use Î”â€‹ğ’˜â€‹(ğ•‚)Î”ğ’˜ğ•‚\Delta{\bm{w}}({\mathbb{K}}) to denote a determinate value without randomness where the client selection ğ•‚ğ•‚{\mathbb{K}} is determined. The rule for Î”â€‹ğ¥Î”ğ¥\Delta{\mathbf{l}} and Î”â€‹ğ’â€‹(ğ•‚)Î”ğ’ğ•‚\Delta{\bm{l}}({\mathbb{K}}) in the following contents is the same.

Based on this assumption, we can easily show that the loss changes in each communication round follow a Gaussian Process under first-order approximation, with the property of Gaussian Distribution.

Corollary 1.

Remark

Although an uniformly sampled client selection is required in AssumptionÂ 1 to get the loss changes to follow a GP prior, it is not necessary for the final selection to be uniformly sampled since we are predicting its loss changes with the GP posterior conditioned on the selected clients. We can view each posterior during the iterative selection process in SectionÂ 4.3 as the distribution of the loss changes w.r.t. the client selection that consists of two parts: (i) fixed selected clients in the previous iteration and (ii) uniformly sampled clients from the rest of the clients.

A.2 Proof of LemmaÂ 1

To prove LemmaÂ 1, we first introduce another assumption.

Assumption 2.

In any communication round tğ‘¡t, for any client selection ğ•‚ğ•‚{\mathbb{K}}, we have

Pâ€‹râ€‹(ğ•‚|Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚tâ€‹(ğ•‚))â‰ˆ1.ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ•‚Î”superscriptsubscriptğ’ğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ•‚1Pr({\mathbb{K}}|\Delta{\bm{l}}_{{\mathbb{K}}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}}))\approx 1. (21)

This assumption asserts that for any client selection ğ•‚ğ•‚{\mathbb{K}}, there is unlikely another client selection other than ğ•‚ğ•‚{\mathbb{K}} which can produce the same loss changes on ğ•‚ğ•‚{\mathbb{K}}, i.e.,

âˆ€ğ•‚â€²,ğ•‚âŠ†ğ•Œ,|ğ•‚â€²|=|ğ•‚|formulae-sequencefor-allsuperscriptğ•‚â€²ğ•‚ğ•Œsuperscriptğ•‚â€²ğ•‚\displaystyle\forall{\mathbb{K}}^{\prime},{\mathbb{K}}\subseteq{\mathbb{U}},|{\mathbb{K}}^{\prime}|=|{\mathbb{K}}| (22)
â‡’â‡’\displaystyle\Rightarrow Pâ€‹râ€‹(Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚tâ€‹(ğ•‚â€²)=Î”â€‹ğ’ğ•‚tâ€‹(ğ•‚)|ğ•‚â€²â‰ ğ•‚)â‰ˆ0.ğ‘ƒğ‘ŸÎ”superscriptsubscriptğ’ğ•‚ğ‘¡superscriptğ•‚â€²conditionalÎ”superscriptsubscriptğ’ğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ•‚superscriptğ•‚â€²ğ•‚0\displaystyle Pr(\Delta{\bm{l}}_{{\mathbb{K}}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}}^{\prime})=\Delta{\bm{l}}_{{\mathbb{K}}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}})|{\mathbb{K}}^{\prime}\neq{\mathbb{K}})\approx 0.

We anticipate that this is a realistic assumption because of the heterogeneity between clients and the highly complexity of the neural network. When selecting different clients, the data used for training varies a lot under heterogeneous federated learning settings. This fact makes it almost impossible to produce the same neural network, and thus the same loss changes, with two different client selections. Furthermore, the selected clients usually have larger loss decreases than other clients who are not selected, because the model update is based on the mean cumulative gradient of these selected clients. The other client selection is unlikely to generate the same large loss decreases on all of them.

With AssumptionÂ 2, we can get the following corollaryÂ 2.

Corollary 2.

In any communication round tğ‘¡t, for any client selection ğ•‚ğ•‚{\mathbb{K}}, we have

Appendix B Selection Criterion and Convergence Analysis

In this section, we will analyse FedCor when selecting arbitrary number of clients. While the iterative client selection makes it obscure to analyse the convergence, we will show that we can construct a simpler proxy algorithm who can approximate the selection strategy of FedCor and there for share similar convergence characteristic. We will prove the convergence of this proxy algorithm.

B.1 Definitions

We first introduce some important definitions. In the following analysis, We denote the client selection sampled from FedCor as ğ•‚tâˆ¼Ï€similar-tosubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğœ‹{\mathbb{K}}_{t}\sim\pi and client selection sampled uniformly as ğ•‚tâˆ¼ğ’°similar-tosubscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ’°{\mathbb{K}}_{t}\sim\mathcal{U}.

We define the posterior gain of this iteration as the decrease from prior mean to posterior mean, namely,

Unfortunately, because of the iterative selection, the selection criterion of kjsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—k_{j} depends on the previous selected clients, which makes a quantitatively analysis complicated. We find that a proxy client selection strategy that maximizes this lower bound has a similar but simpler behaviour compared with FedCor, and we will also give a convergence guarantee of the proxy algorithm.

B.2 Approximation of FedCor

An important property of FedCor is that it prefers clients who have lower correlations with those selected in the previous iteration, since

âˆ€rkjâˆ’1â€‹kjt,jâˆ’1âˆˆ(âˆ’1,1),âˆ‚gt,jâ€‹(kj)âˆ‚rkjâˆ’1â€‹kjt,jâˆ’1<0.formulae-sequencefor-allsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—11superscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—0\forall r^{t,j-1}_{k_{j-1}k_{j}}\in(-1,1),\frac{\partial g^{t,j}(k_{j})}{\partial r^{t,j-1}_{k_{j-1}k_{j}}}<0. (58)

We further predict that FedCor tends to select clients that with rkjâˆ’1â€‹kjt,jâˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—r^{t,j-1}_{k_{j-1}k_{j}} close to 00 instead of rkjâˆ’1â€‹kjt,jâˆ’1<0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—0r^{t,j-1}_{k_{j-1}k_{j}}<0 because if rkjâˆ’1â€‹kjt,jâˆ’1<0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—0r^{t,j-1}_{k_{j-1}k_{j}}<0, kjsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—k_{j} should be far away from kjâˆ’1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—1k_{j-1} who is closed to other clients in the embedding space, which makes kjsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—k_{j} has low correlation with the other clients and not be selected. Therefore, we can infer that FedCor will select a group of clients who have nearly zero correlations with each other, which simplifies the expression of gt,jâ€‹(kj)superscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—g^{t,j}(k_{j}) to gt,1â€‹(kj)superscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—g^{t,1}(k_{j}).

Based on the analysis above, we define a proxy algorithm Ï€~~ğœ‹\tilde{\pi} who maximize the following objective.

A~t=âˆ‘kjâˆˆğ•‚tCgt,1â€‹(kj)â‰ˆâˆ‘kâˆˆğ•‚tâˆ‘ipiâ€‹Î£i,kt,superscript~ğ´ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡ğ¶superscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ•‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle\tilde{A}^{t}=\sum_{k_{j}\in{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}^{C}g^{t,1}(k_{j})\approx\sum_{k\in{\mathbb{K}}_{t}}\sum_{i}p_{i}\Sigma^{t}_{i,k}, (59)

where we further omit the difference of Î±ktsuperscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\alpha_{k}^{t} and Ïƒktsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¡\sigma_{k}^{t} for different client kğ‘˜k. We can use the client selection generated by this proxy algorithm to approximate the client selection of FedCor, and thus they share similar convergence characteristic.

In the following section, we will show that this proxy algorithm has a good property that enable it to converge to the optimal solution of the global loss Lğ¿L without gap, even it is a biased selection strategy.

Appendix C Experiment Details

We simulate the training process of federated learning on one machine. All experiments in this paper are run on one NVIDIA 2080-Ti GPU and two Intel Xeon E5-2630 v4 CPUs. The experiments on FMNIST require around 3 hours for each seed, and the experiments on CIFAR-10 require around 10 hours for each seed.

C.1 Model Parameters

Hyperparameters in FMNIST

We follow [4] to construct the neural model on FMNIST: An MLP model with two hidden layers with 646464 and 303030 units, respectively. Under all three heterogeneous settings, we set the local batch size B=64ğµ64B=64 and the number of local iterations E=20ğ¸20E=20. The learning rate Î·0subscriptğœ‚0\eta_{0} is set to 0.0050.0050.005 initially, and halved at the 150-th and 300-th rounds. An SGD optimizer with a weight decay of 0.00010.00010.0001 and no momentum is used. We allocate data to N=100ğ‘100N=100 clients, and set the participation fraction C=10ğ¶10C=10 for the 1SPC setting, and C=5ğ¶5C=5 for the 2SPC and Dir settings.

Hyperparameters in CIFAR-10

We use a CNN with three convolutional layersÂ [29] with 323232, 646464 and 646464 kernels, respectively. And all convolution kernels are of size 3Ã—3333\times 3. Finally, the outputs of convolutional layers are fed into a fully-connected layer with 64 units. Under all three heterogeneous settings, we set the local batch size B=50ğµ50B=50 and the number of local iterations E=40ğ¸40E=40. We use a learning rate Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 without learning rate decay, and a weight decay of 0.00030.00030.0003 for the SGD optimizer. The total number of clients and the client participation fraction are the same as those in FMNIST.

Hyperparameters for FedCor

We set the dimension of client embedding d=15ğ‘‘15d=15 for all experiments. In Eq.Â 16, we set M=10,S=1formulae-sequenceğ‘€10ğ‘†1M=10,S=1 for the warm-up phase, and M=1,S=1formulae-sequenceğ‘€1ğ‘†1M=1,S=1 for the normal phase. And we set the discount factor Î³=Î¸Î”â€‹tğ›¾superscriptğœƒÎ”ğ‘¡\gamma=\theta^{\Delta t} where Î¸=0.9ğœƒ0.9\theta=0.9 for experiments on FMNIST and Î¸=0.99ğœƒ0.99\theta=0.99 for experiments on CIFAR-10. In each GP update round tğ‘¡t, we use ğ‘¿tâˆ’1superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡1{\bm{X}}^{t-1} as the initialization and use an Adam optimizerÂ [11] with learning rate 0.010.010.01 to optimize for ğ‘¿tsuperscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡{\bm{X}}^{t}. Notice that although Eq.Â 16 has a closed form optimal solution for ğ‘¿tsuperscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡{\bm{X}}^{t}, we still learn ğ‘¿tsuperscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡{\bm{X}}^{t} with the gradient decent method with the initialization ğ‘¿tâˆ’1superscriptğ‘¿ğ‘¡1{\bm{X}}^{t-1} in order to utilize the covariance stationarity and reduce the evaluation bias with small number of samples.

Hyperparameters for other baselines

We use the same parameters Î±1=0.75,Î±2=0.01formulae-sequencesubscriptğ›¼10.75subscriptğ›¼20.01\alpha_{1}=0.75,\alpha_{2}=0.01 and Î±3=0.1subscriptğ›¼30.1\alpha_{3}=0.1 as those in the paperÂ [6] for Active Federated Learning. And we set d=2â€‹Nâ€‹Cğ‘‘2ğ‘ğ¶d=2NC for Power-of-choice Selection Strategy, which is empirically shown to be the best value of dğ‘‘d in a highly heterogeneous setting in the paperÂ [4].

Note that we implement the random selection strategy as uniformly sampling clients from ğ•Œğ•Œ{\mathbb{U}} without replacementÂ [23], while Cho et al.[4] implement the random selection strategy as sampling clients with replacement. Thus, our implemented random selection strategy achieves better performances than their implementation.

C.2 Dirichlet Distribution for Data Partition

We follow the idea inÂ [7] to construct the Dir heterogeneous setting, while we make some modifications to get an unbalanced non-identical data distribution.

For each client kğ‘˜k, we sample the data distribution ğ’’kâˆˆâ„10subscriptğ’’ğ‘˜superscriptâ„10\bm{q}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{10} from a dirichlet distribution independently, which could be formulated as

ğ’’kâˆ¼Dirâ€‹(Î±â€‹ğ’‘),similar-tosubscriptğ’’ğ‘˜Dirğ›¼ğ’‘\bm{q}_{k}\sim\text{Dir}(\alpha\bm{p}), (146)

where ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} is the prior label distribution and Î±âˆˆâ„+ğ›¼subscriptâ„\alpha\in\mathbb{R}_{+} is the concentration parameter of the dirichlet distribution. We group ğ’’ksubscriptğ’’ğ‘˜\bm{q}_{k} of all the clients together and get a fraction matrix Q=[ğ’’1,â‹¯,ğ’’n]ğ‘„subscriptğ’’1â‹¯subscriptğ’’ğ‘›Q=[\bm{q}_{1},\cdots,\bm{q}_{n}]. We denote the size of dataset on each client as ğ’™=[x1,â‹¯,xN]Tğ’™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘‡\bm{x}=[x_{1},\cdots,x_{N}]^{T} and we get it from a solution of a quadratic programming:

minğ’™subscriptğ’™\displaystyle\min_{\bm{x}}\quad ğ’™Tâ€‹ğ’™superscriptğ’™ğ‘‡ğ’™\displaystyle\bm{x}^{T}\bm{x} (147)
subject to Qâ€‹ğ’™=ğ’…ğ‘„ğ’™ğ’…\displaystyle Q\bm{x}=\bm{d} (148)
ğ’™âˆˆâ„++N,ğ’™superscriptsubscriptâ„absentğ‘\displaystyle\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}_{++}^{N}, (149)

where ğ’…ğ’…\bm{d} is the number of data with each label. We minimize â€–ğ’™â€–2subscriptnormğ’™2\|\bm{x}\|_{2} to avoid the cases where data distribution is over-concentrated on a small fraction of clients. In that case, the client selection problem might become trivial, since we can always ignore those clients with a small dataset and select those with a large dataset.

Appendix D Extra Experimental Results

D.1 Ablation Study: Annealing Coefficient

We conduct experiments on FMNIST and CIFAR-10 with different annealing coefficient Î²ğ›½\beta. We setup our experiments under three heterogeneous settings as in SectionÂ 5, with different annealing coefficient Î²ğ›½\beta (Î²=0.95,0.75,0.5ğ›½0.950.750.5\beta=0.95,0.75,0.5 for FMNIST and Î²=0.97,0.95,0.9ğ›½0.970.950.9\beta=0.97,0.95,0.9 for CIFAR-10). We fix the GP training interval Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t to 101010 for FMNIST and 505050 for CIFAR-10. The test accuracy curves are shown in FigureÂ 8. We can see that within a large range, the value of annealing coefficient only slightly influence the convergence rate as well as the final accuracy. Recalling the results of different GP training intervals Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t in SectionÂ 5.3, we can say that our method is not sensitive to the hyperparameters Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t and Î²ğ›½\beta.

We present the selected frequency of each client in FigureÂ 10 and FigureÂ 11 for FMNIST and CIFAR-10 respectively. We can see that with a smaller Î²ğ›½\beta, the selected frequency tends to be more â€œuniformâ€. However, this does not mean that our selection strategy is equivalent to the uniformly random selection. Our sequential selection strategy introduces dependencies between selected clients as discussed in the multi-iteration insights in SectionÂ 4.3, which makes our selection strategy prefer some combinations of selected clients to others, while the uniformly random selection treats all the combinations equally. The advantage shown in FigureÂ 8 compared to the uniformly random strategy demonstrates that selecting a good combination of clients, not only a good individual, is important.

D.2 Normality Verification

We setup experiments to show that Gaussian Distribution can model the loss changes w.r.t. uniformly sampled client selection. To verify this, in the last round of the warm-up phase, we perform the following procedure to examine the normality.

  1. 1.

    We uniformly sample 100010001000 different client selections {ğ•Št,i:i=1,â‹¯,1000}conditional-setsubscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘–1â‹¯1000\{{\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}:i=1,\cdots,1000\} and collect the corresponding loss changes Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•Št,i)=[Î”â€‹l1tâ€‹(ğ•Št,i),â‹¯,Î”â€‹lNtâ€‹(ğ•Št,i)]Î”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–Î”superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–â‹¯Î”superscriptsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–\Delta{\bm{l}}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i})=[\Delta l_{1}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}),\cdots,\Delta l_{N}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i})] for each of them.

  2. 2.

    We perform PCA on {Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•Št,i):i=1,â‹¯,1000}conditional-setÎ”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•Šğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘–1â‹¯1000\{\Delta{\bm{l}}^{t}({\mathbb{S}}_{t,i}):i=1,\cdots,1000\} to extract the principle components.

  3. 3.

    We plot the histogram of each principle component and compare its distribution with the Gaussian Distribution.

We do not use Multivariate Normality Test directly because we find that ğšºğ’•superscriptğšºğ’•\bm{\Sigma^{t}} is always nearly singular, which makes the Multivariate Normality Test unstable. Thus, we turn to perform PCA and visualize each principle component to verify the normality.

The results of FMNIST and CIFAR-10 are shown in FigureÂ 12 and FigureÂ 13 respectively. The red line shows the probability density of Gaussian Distribution with the mean and variance of that principle component. We can see that in all our experiments, Gaussian Distribution can fit the distribution of the principle component well, which verifies that LemmaÂ 1 does hold in all the experiment settings.

D.3 Covariance Stationarity Verification

We examine that assumption in SectionÂ 4.5 that the covariance keep approximately stationary during the FL training, namely,

âˆ€t,ğšºtâ‰ˆğšºt+Î”â€‹t.for-allğ‘¡superscriptğšºğ‘¡superscriptğšºğ‘¡Î”ğ‘¡\forall t,{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t}\approx{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t+\Delta t}. (150)

To verify this, every Î”â€‹tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta t rounds (Î”â€‹t=10Î”ğ‘¡10\Delta t=10 for FMNIST and Î”â€‹t=50Î”ğ‘¡50\Delta t=50 for CIFAR-10), we randomly sample 100010001000 client selections ğ•‚isubscriptğ•‚ğ‘–{\mathbb{K}}_{i} and collect the corresponding loss changes Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•‚i)Î”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘–\Delta{\bm{l}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}}_{i}). We directly calculate the covariance matrix ğšºtsuperscriptğšºğ‘¡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t} with these samples {Î”â€‹ğ’tâ€‹(ğ•‚i):i=1,â‹¯,1000}conditional-setÎ”superscriptğ’ğ‘¡subscriptğ•‚ğ‘–ğ‘–1â‹¯1000\{\Delta{\bm{l}}^{t}({\mathbb{K}}_{i}):i=1,\cdots,1000\}. Then for each adjacent pair of covariance matrix, we calculate their cosine similarity as follows.

similarityâ€‹(ğšºt,ğšºt+Î”â€‹t)=trâ€‹(ğšºtTâ€‹ğšºt+Î”â€‹t)trâ€‹(ğšºtTâ€‹ğšºt)â€‹trâ€‹(ğšºt+Î”â€‹tTâ€‹ğšºt+Î”â€‹t)similaritysuperscriptğšºtsuperscriptğšºtÎ”ttrsuperscriptsuperscriptğšºtTsuperscriptğšºtÎ”ttrsuperscriptsuperscriptğšºtTsuperscriptğšºttrsuperscriptsuperscriptğšºtÎ”tTsuperscriptğšºtÎ”t\rm{similarity}({\bm{\Sigma}}^{t},{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t+\Delta t})=\frac{\rm{tr}({{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t}}^{T}{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t+\Delta t})}{\rm{tr}({{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t}}^{T}{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t})\rm{tr}({{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t+\Delta t}}^{T}{\bm{\Sigma}}^{t+\Delta t})} (151)

The similarity is in range [0,1]01[0,1], and a larger one shows a higher similarity.

The results are shown in FigureÂ 9. We can see that in most cases the similarity is larger than 0.90.90.9, which verifies our claim of the covariance stationarity.
